awd_titl_txt: Workshop: Addressing the Nexus of Food, Energy and Water in the Context of Societal Challenges, Mar 1-3, 2017, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India
awd_abstract_narration:
1664375
Ray

Food security is civilization's next critical challenge, as the current world population of seven billion is projected to increase to more than nine billion by 2050. The United States (US) will face pressure to produce more food and feed for export, straining its energy and water resources and impacting ecosystem services. This three-day workshop will bring together experts from the fields of agronomy, agricultural economics and trade policy, water resources science/engineering, atmospheric sciences, and natural resource management to further investigate the issues and to develop new recommendations in the context of sustainability and water productivity. The workshop will be held in Bangalore, India (at the campus of the Indian Institute of Science), March 1 - 3, 2017.

Intensity of agriculture, excess pumping, and climatic (rainfall) shifts are straining many regional aquifer systems in the US and around the world. This workshop will address the pressing questions of how to better balance demands on these aquifers under the current pumping stresses, and help identify the cropping management systems that will be necessary to cope with future climatic shifts. The collaboration will enable US and Indian researchers to share research and expertise aimed at solving the challenges of producing more food with less water and energy, while protecting the quality of scarce freshwater resources for human consumption and ecosystem services. The researchers will benefit from receiving international science perspectives as well as socio-economics perspectives at the nexus of food-energy-water. The outcomes of the workshop will advance national discussion about innovations at the nexus of food-energy-water, for which NSF has committed significant investments. The main goal of the proposed workshop is to address societal challenges in feeding humanity in the coming century and how the nexus between food, water and energy can be exploited to address sustainability challenges. Although these challenges are different in India and United States because of the scale of mechanization, resources availability, and other factors, the workshop will address differences and similarities in these challenges to develop mutually beneficial solutions. The specific objectives of the workshop include: 1. Identify innovative methods to improve water and energy use efficiency in the context of the nexus in both Indian and US settings, 2. Understand how the nexus concept in the food, energy and water systems can be a driver in economic and social decision making. To address food security issues, researchers have started to estimate current yield gaps, which represent the difference between current yield and the maximum yield that can be obtained under optimum management conditions. Efforts are underway to develop a yield gap analysis on a global scale to delineate areas where there is potential to increase crop yields. In order to analyze the sustainability of enhanced production of food crops (whether in the U.S. or elsewhere in the world) one needs to do the following in a step-wise manner: (1) analyze the yield gap for a given crop or suite of crops through crop modeling with optimal management scenarios and selection of proper crop hybrids; (2) for various scenarios in yield gap, estimate the water and nutrient fluxes leaving the root zone; (3) using appropriate numerical models, estimate the groundwater level changes, stream depletion, and changes in water quality in the aquifer based on the pumping needs and return fluxes of water and nutrients; and, (4) simulate optimal power use for irrigation systems. This workshop will lead to development of realistic and transferable management scenarios, tools and technologies to address societal challenges in food, energy and water security. Graduate students and postdocs as well as researchers that are in early stages of their careers will be encouraged to participate. The proceedings from the workshop will be published in electronic form, and widely shared by the Nebraska Water Center with potential stakeholders through newsletters, press releases and two annual sponsored faculty retreats.

por.por_cntn:
A growing global population, which is expected to increase 35 percent by 2050, coupled with a higher calorie intake per individual has triggered a need for increased food production. Between 1960 and 2010, the world population increased from three to seven billion, which led to the introduction of hybrids in the years of the green revolution (1960’s and early 1970’s) and investments in irrigation, nutrients and crop protection chemicals. However, scientists now have observed yield plateaus for several crops in a number of countries. Remaining areas of arable land are typically less productive or located in marginal areas, thus unless significant breakthroughs in genetic improvements of photosynthesis or drought tolerance is achieved, a jump in yield remains elusive.

Food security is more challenging for India because of its 1.25 billion people, limited land area, scarcity of water and energy, and climate change. In India, consumption of meat products has gone up from 5% to 12% and that rate is rising rapidly. As incomes rise, more consumption of food/feed will require more use of resources. In India, the current level of food production is already stressing its water and energy resources, and future demand can only be met by technological advancements in irrigation, soil health, crop cultivar developments, energy efficiency, and significant educational efforts to the agriculture sector. Rising incomes will also encourage India to import food from countries like United States (US). The US issues will be centered around the utilization of its energy and water resources to produce food to meet the export demands without compromising its quality of living and severely affecting ecosystem services.

During this workshop, both the Indian and US researchers presented several new technologies and methods to measure crop water productivity, water use efficiency, and water footprint computations. Precision farming practices (planting, irrigation, and harvesting) for large and small-holder farms were discussed. In addition, various presentations from India and US show-cased remote sensing tools used to measure crop water productivity. The implications of promoting biofuel production on both land and water resources were also discussed. Particularly, the severity of ground water pollution in areas undergoing intense agricultural production and dissolution of arsenic (India) and uranium (US) from aquifer sedimentary deposits were discussed. What was striking was that despite the advancement of technologies in farming and a skyrocketing production, the income gap between the rural and urban communities in the US seems to be growing with time. Depopulation of rural areas in the US and India are particularly concerning as the young population starts migrating to cities for better jobs.

 Major recommendations of the event: Three panel discussions took place over the three-day period in which the first panel was focused on issues in India and US, the second panel examined the nexus of food, energy, and water, and the third panel was focused on solution strategies. Water productivity computations for major crops, spatial scale of water footprint computations, improved modeling approaches to assess ground water depletion, remote sensing and information communication tools for soil moisture and crop assessment, and use of geospatial methods for upscaling were some of the major recommendations. Additionally, interfacing of social science with technology and quantification of sustainability was recommended.

 Principal Output

  • This workshop formed the basis for a joint research proposal to the Innovations at the Nexus of Food, Energy, and Water Systems of US National Science Foundation that was submitted during the last call (September 26, 2018).
  • A contract has been signed with Springer publishing to generate a book volume based on the workshop and the book is expected to be ready by the summer of 2019.
  • The workshop helped generate student interest in exchange programs and joint publications. One student from the Indian Institute of Science (IISc) has already visited US and is working on a joint publication. One US student was to spend six months at IISc under a fellowship from the Department of Science and Technology of India to study water, energy, and food issues. The student took a permanent job in Ethiopia and we are looking for new students for next year.
  • Additionally, faculty sabbaticals are being considered as opportunities for future collaborations.

 Major Outcome

The workshop showed that the problems between rural and urban areas are remarkably similar in US and India and huge income gaps exist. The US is likely to remain as a major food and feed producer for the future decades, while facing increasing pressure to manage its water and energy resources for sustainability.
